clinical_study.brief_title: Study of Fibrinogen Metabolism During Severe Trauma and Burns
clinical_study.official_title: Alteration in Fibrinogen Metabolism in Patients With Severe Burns and Traumatic Injuries

lead_sponsor.agency: United States Army Institute of Surgical Research

clinical_study.source: United States Army Institute of Surgical Research

brief_summary.textblock: To study the fibrinogen metabolic changes in relation to coagulation disorder in patients with severe burns and trauma injuries. As a result of the burn or trauma injury breakdown of fibrinogen is accelerated.

detailed_description.textblock: In this protocol, we will investigate fibrinogen metabolism in burn and trauma patients, using an 8h infusion of stable isotopes labeled amino acids (1-13C-phenylalanine, 2H5-phenylalanine, and 2H3-ketoisocaporate). The increase of the labeled amino acids incorporating into fibrinogen during the infusion and the decay of labeled fibrinogen after stopping the isotopes infusion (as measured by GC-MS) will be used to calculate fibrinogen synthesis and degradation. Stable isotopes are non-radioactive.

primary_outcome.measure: During the flow phase following burn or trauma injury, fibrinogen degradation is accelerated

secondary_outcome.measure: Fibrinogen degradation stimulates fibrinogen synthesis at the expense of whole body protein catabolism

arm_group.description: Patients who have sustained burn injury greater than or equal to 20% of total body surface area

study_pop.textblock: Burn patients Trauma patients Healthy Volunteers

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- 20% total body surface area burn or more
- severe trauma with injury severity score greater than 10
- between ages of 18 and 65 years
Exclusion Criteria:
- history of blood clotting disorder
- history of liver disease such as cirrhosis or hepatitis
- pregnant or nursing
- allergic to iodine, shellfish or dye used in X-Rays
- taking long term medications for blood clotting usch as Coumadin or Plavix
- prisoners
- receiving total parenteral nutrition
